title: Kenya: Comply and Suspend Teachers' Strike, Judge Orders Unions
text:
Namibia: Some Protesting Struggle Kids Have Diplomas By Abiud Ochieng 
Employment and Labour Relations Court Judge Nelson Abuodha has directed teachers' unions to comply with his Friday orders requiring them to suspend their strike. 
The judge declined a request by the Kenya National Union of Teachers (Knut) and Kenya Union of Post Primary Education Teachers (Kuppet) to have his orders stopped, saying the unions have a duty to comply because they will still need the court's services in the future. 
"I plead with the union officials to advice their members to respect the orders of this court as they will need its protection tomorrow as they always have. 
"In conclusion, I decline to stop or make any comment on my orders which directed the union members to resume teaching," said Justice Abuodha. 
In the same orders, the judge had also directed the union officials to assist the Cabinet secretary for Labour to appoint a neutral and mutually agreeable conciliator or conciliation committee within the next 30 days. 
The appointed team was to discuss how the June 30 award, giving teachers a 50-60 per cent pay rise, could be implemented. 
The unions had requested Justice Abuodha to stop the orders directing teachers to resume teaching immediately given that there is an ongoing appeal at the Court of Appeal. 
The Teachers Service Commission is challenging the 50-60 per cent pay award to teachers at the appeals court. 
The unions had requested the judge to stop the implementation of the order so as to await the outcome of the appeal. Kenya
